tool.name: certtool
tool.title: GnuTLS certificate tool
tool.detail:
Tool to parse and generate X.509 certificates, requests and private keys.
It can be used interactively or non interactively by
specifying the template command line option.

The tool accepts files or supported URIs via the --infile option. In case PIN
is required for URI access you can provide it using the environment variables GNUTLS_PIN 
and GNUTLS_SO_PIN.

options.description: Enable debugging
options.detail: Specifies the debug level.

options.description: More verbose output
Input file
Output file
Perform validation at the timestamp instead of the system time
options.detail:
timestamp is an instance in time encoded as Unix time or in a human
 readable timestring such as "29 Feb 2004", "2004-02-29".
Full documentation available at 
<https://www.gnu.org/software/coreutils/manual/html_node/Date-input-formats.html>
or locally via info '(coreutils) date invocation'.

options.description: Print information on the given certificate
Print information on a public key
options.detail: The option combined with --load-request, --load-pubkey, --load-privkey and --load-certificate will extract the public key of the object in question.

options.description: Generate a self-signed certificate
Generate a signed certificate
Generates a proxy certificate
Update a signed certificate
Print the fingerprint of the given certificate
options.detail: This is a simple hash of the DER encoding of the certificate. It can be combined with the --hash parameter. However, it is recommended for identification to use the key-id which depends only on the certificate's key.

options.description: Print the key ID of the given certificate
options.detail: This is a hash of the public key of the given certificate. It identifies the key uniquely, remains the same on a certificate renewal and depends only on signed fields of the certificate.

options.description: Print certificate's public key
options.detail: This option is deprecated as a duplicate of --pubkey-info

options.description: Generate an X.509 version 1 certificate (with no extensions)
Sign a certificate with a specific signature algorithm
options.detail:
This option can be combined with --generate-certificate, to sign the certificate with
a specific signature algorithm variant. The only option supported is 'RSA-PSS', and should be
specified when the signer does not have a certificate which is marked for RSA-PSS use only.

options.description: Print information on the given certificate request
Generate a PKCS #10 certificate request
options.detail: Will generate a PKCS #10 certificate request. To specify a private key use --load-privkey.

options.description: Do not use extensions in certificate requests
Print information on a PKCS #12 structure
options.detail: This option will dump the contents and print the metadata of the provided PKCS #12 structure.

options.description: The PKCS #12 friendly name to use
options.detail: The name to be used for the primary certificate and private key in a PKCS #12 file.

options.description: Generate a PKCS #12 structure
options.detail: It requires a certificate, a private key and possibly a CA certificate to be specified.

options.description: Print information on a private key
Print information on a PKCS #8 structure
options.detail: This option will print information about encrypted PKCS #8 structures. That option does not require the decryption of the structure.

options.description: Convert an RSA-PSS key to raw RSA format
options.detail:
It requires an RSA-PSS key as input and will output a raw RSA
key. This command is necessary for compatibility with applications that
cannot read RSA-PSS keys.

options.description: Generate a private key
options.detail:
When generating RSA-PSS or RSA-OAEP private keys, the --hash option will
restrict the allowed hash for the key; For RSA-PSS keys the --salt-size
option is also acceptable.

options.description: Specify the key type to use on key generation
options.detail:
This option can be combined with --generate-privkey, to specify
the key type to be generated. Valid options are, 'rsa', 'rsa-pss', 'rsa-oaep', 'dsa', 'ecdsa', 'ed25519, 'ed448', 'x25519', and 'x448'.'.
When combined with certificate generation it can be used to specify an
RSA-PSS certificate when an RSA key is given.

options.description: Specify the number of bits for key generation
Specify the curve used for EC key generation
options.detail: Supported values are secp192r1, secp224r1, secp256r1, secp384r1 and secp521r1.

options.description: Specify the security level [low, legacy, medium, high, ultra]
options.detail: This is alternative to the bits option.

options.description: Convert a given key to a PKCS #8 structure
options.detail: This needs to be combined with --load-privkey.

options.description: Use PKCS #8 format for private keys
Generate a private key or parameters from a seed using a provable method
options.detail:
This will use the FIPS PUB186-4 algorithms (i.e., Shawe-Taylor) for provable key generation.
When specified the private keys or parameters will be generated from a seed, and can be
later validated with --verify-provable-privkey to be correctly generated from the seed. You may
specify --seed or allow GnuTLS to generate one (recommended). This option can be combined with
--generate-privkey or --generate-dh-params.

That option applies to RSA and DSA keys. On the DSA keys the PQG parameters
are generated using the seed, and on RSA the two primes.

options.description: Verify a private key generated from a seed using a provable method
options.detail: This will use the FIPS-186-4 algorithms for provable key generation. You may specify --seed or use the seed stored in the private key structure.

options.description: When generating a private key use the given hex-encoded seed
options.detail:
The seed acts as a security parameter for the private key, and
thus a seed size which corresponds to the security level of the private key
should be provided (e.g., 256-bits seed).

options.description: Print information on the given CRL structure
Generate a CRL
options.detail:
This option generates a Certificate Revocation List. When combined with --load-crl it would use the loaded CRL as base for the generated (i.e., all revoked certificates in the base will be copied to the new CRL).
To add new certificates to the CRL use --load-certificate.

options.description: Verify a Certificate Revocation List using a trusted list
options.detail: The trusted certificate list must be loaded with --load-ca-certificate.

options.description: Verify a PEM encoded certificate chain
options.detail:
Verifies the validity of a certificate chain. That is, an ordered set of
certificates where each one is the issuer of the previous, and the first is
the end-certificate to be validated. In a proper chain the last certificate
is a self signed one. It can be combined with --verify-purpose or --verify-hostname.

options.description: Verify a PEM encoded certificate (chain) against a trusted set
options.detail:
The trusted certificate list can be loaded with --load-ca-certificate. If no
certificate list is provided, then the system's trusted certificate list is used. Note that
during verification multiple paths may be explored. On a successful verification
the successful path will be the last one. It can be combined with --verify-purpose or --verify-hostname.

options.description: Specify a hostname to be used for certificate chain verification
options.detail: This is to be combined with one of the verify certificate options.

options.description: Specify a email to be used for certificate chain verification
options.detail: This is to be combined with one of the verify certificate options.

options.description: Specify a purpose OID to be used for certificate chain verification
options.detail: This object identifier restricts the purpose of the certificates to be verified. Example purposes are 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.1 (TLS WWW), 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.4 (EMAIL) etc. Note that a CA certificate without a purpose set (extended key usage) is valid for any purpose.

options.description: Allow broken algorithms, such as MD5 for verification
options.detail: This can be combined with --p7-verify, --verify or --verify-chain.

options.description: Specify a security level profile to be used for verification
options.detail:
This option can be used to specify a certificate verification profile. Certificate
    verification profiles correspond to the security level. This should be one of
    'none', 'very weak', 'low', 'legacy', 'medium', 'high', 'ultra',
    'future'. Note that by default no profile is applied, unless one is set
    as minimum in the gnutls configuration file.

options.description: Generate a PKCS #7 structure
options.detail: This option generates a PKCS #7 certificate container structure. To add certificates in the structure use --load-certificate and --load-crl.

options.description: Signs using a PKCS #7 structure
options.detail: This option generates a PKCS #7 structure containing a signature for the provided data from infile. The data are stored within the structure. The signer certificate has to be specified using --load-certificate and --load-privkey. The input to --load-certificate can be a list of certificates. In case of a list, the first certificate is used for signing and the other certificates are included in the structure.

options.description: Signs using a detached PKCS #7 structure
options.detail: This option generates a PKCS #7 structure containing a signature for the provided data from infile. The signer certificate has to be specified using --load-certificate and --load-privkey. The input to --load-certificate can be a list of certificates. In case of a list, the first certificate is used for signing and the other certificates are included in the structure.

options.description: The signer's certificate will be included in the cert list
options.detail: This options works with --p7-sign or --p7-detached-sign and will include or exclude the signer's certificate into the generated signature.

options.description: Will include a timestamp in the PKCS #7 structure
options.detail: This option will include a timestamp in the generated signature

options.description: Will show the embedded data in the PKCS #7 structure
options.detail: This option can be combined with --p7-verify or --p7-info and will display the embedded signed data in the PKCS #7 structure.

options.description: Print information on a PKCS #7 structure
Verify the provided PKCS #7 structure
options.detail: This option verifies the signed PKCS #7 structure. The certificate list to use for verification can be specified with --load-ca-certificate. When no certificate list is provided, then the system's certificate list is used. Alternatively a direct signer can be provided using --load-certificate. A key purpose can be enforced with the --verify-purpose option, and the --load-data option will utilize detached data.

options.description: Convert S/MIME to PKCS #7 structure
Generate PKCS #3 encoded Diffie-Hellman parameters
options.detail:
The will generate random parameters to be used with
Diffie-Hellman key exchange. The output parameters will be in PKCS #3
format. Note that it is recommended to use the --get-dh-params option
instead.

options.description: List the included PKCS #3 encoded Diffie-Hellman parameters
options.detail:
Returns stored DH parameters in GnuTLS. Those parameters returned
are defined in RFC7919, and can be considered standard parameters for a TLS
key exchange. This option is provided for old applications which require
DH parameters to be specified; modern GnuTLS applications should not require
them.

options.description: Print information PKCS #3 encoded Diffie-Hellman parameters
Loads a private key file
options.detail: This can be either a file or a PKCS #11 URL

options.description: Loads a public key file
options.detail: This can be either a file or a PKCS #11 URL

options.description: Loads a certificate request file
options.detail: This option can be used with a file

options.description: Loads a certificate file
options.detail: This option can be used with a file

options.description: Loads the certificate authority's private key file
options.detail: This can be either a file or a PKCS #11 URL

options.description: Loads the certificate authority's certificate file
options.detail: This can be either a file or a PKCS #11 URL

options.description: Loads the provided CRL
options.detail: This option can be used with a file

options.detail: This option can be used with a file

options.description: Password to use
options.detail: You can use this option to specify the password in the command line instead of reading it from the tty. Note, that the command line arguments are available for view in others in the system. Specifying password as '' is the same as specifying no password.

options.description: Enforce a NULL password
options.detail: This option enforces a NULL password. This is different than the empty or no password in schemas like PKCS #8.

options.description: Enforce an empty password
options.detail: This option enforces an empty password. This is different than the NULL or no password in schemas like PKCS #8.

options.description: Print big number in an easier format to parse
In certain operations it prints the information in C-friendly format
options.detail: In certain operations it prints the information in C-friendly format, suitable for including into C programs.

options.description: Generate RSA key
options.detail: When combined with --generate-privkey generates an RSA private key.

options.description: Generate DSA key
options.detail: When combined with --generate-privkey generates a DSA private key.

options.description: Generate ECC (ECDSA) key
options.detail: When combined with --generate-privkey generates an elliptic curve private key to be used with ECDSA.

options.description: Hash algorithm to use for signing
options.detail: Available hash functions are SHA1, RMD160, SHA256, SHA384, SHA512, SHA3-224, SHA3-256, SHA3-384, SHA3-512.

options.description: Specify the RSA-PSS key default salt size
options.detail: Typical keys shouldn't set or restrict this option.

options.description: Specify the RSA-OAEP label, encoded in hexadecimal
options.detail: Typical keys shouldn't set or restrict this option.

options.description: Use DER format for input certificates, private keys, and DH parameters
options.detail:
The input files will be assumed to be in DER or RAW format. 
Unlike options that in PEM input would allow multiple input data (e.g. multiple 
certificates), when reading in DER format a single data structure is read.

options.description: Use DER format for output certificates, private keys, and DH parameters
options.detail: The output will be in DER or RAW format.

options.description: No effect
Template file to use for non-interactive operation
Print information to stdout instead of stderr
Enable interaction for entering password when in batch mode
options.detail: This option will enable interaction to enter password when in batch mode. That is useful when the template option has been specified.

options.description: Cipher to use for PKCS #8 and #12 operations
options.detail: Cipher may be one of 3des, 3des-pkcs12, aes-128, aes-192, aes-256, rc2-40, arcfour.

options.description: Specify the PKCS #11 provider library
options.detail: This will override the default options in /etc/gnutls/pkcs11.conf

options.description: Output textual information before PEM-encoded certificates, private keys, etc
options.detail: Output textual information before PEM-encoded data
